headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Mishanta, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome, everyone, to the Exelon Corporation Q4 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I'll now turn the conference over to Mr. Fran
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Mishanta, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome, everyone, to the Exelon Corporation Q4 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I'll now turn the conference over to Mr. Francis Idehen. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mishanta. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our fourth quarter 2015 earnings conference call. Leading the call today are Chris Crane, Exelon's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Jack Thayer, Exelon's Chief Financial Of
componenttext:
Thank you, Mishanta. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our fourth quarter 2015 earnings conference call. 
Leading the call today are Chris Crane, Exelon's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Jack Thayer, Exelon's Chief Financial Officer. They're joined by other members of Exelon's senior management team, who will be available to answer your questions following our prepared remarks. 
We issued our earnings release this morning, along with the presentation, each of which can be found in the Investor Relations section of Exelon's website. 
The earnings release and other matters, which we discuss during today's call contain forward-looking statements and estimates that are subject to various risks and uncertainties. Actual results could differ from our forward-looking statements based on factors and assumptions discussed in the earnings release, today's materials, comments made during this call and in the Risk Factors section of the 2014 10-K and the third quarter 10-Q. Please refer to today's 8-K and 10-K and the 10-Q and Exelon's other filings for a discussion of factors that may cause results to differ from management's projections, forecasts and expectations. 
Today's presentation also includes references to adjusted operating earnings and other non-GAAP measures. Please refer to the information contained in the appendix of our presentation and our earnings release for a reconciliation between the non-GAAP measures to the nearest equivalent GAAP measures. We've scheduled 45 minutes for today's call. 
I'll now turn the call over to Chris Crane, Exelon's CEO.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Francis, and good morning to everybody. Thank you for joining us on our fourth quarter call. Before I go into the results, I want to take a moment to thank our crews who worked hard to restore power for our customers in Baltimore and Philadel
componenttext:
Thank you, Francis, and good morning to everybody. Thank you for joining us on our fourth quarter call. 
Before I go into the results, I want to take a moment to thank our crews who worked hard to restore power for our customers in Baltimore and Philadelphia affected by the January storms. 
BGE and PECO were able to restore approximately 22,000 customers throughout the weather even, keeping the average restoration times to less than 3 hours, which is a remarkable accomplishment given the challenges associated with traveling and the working conditions that has the storm intensified. 
I'll start off by reiterating our strategy and our capital allocation philosophy. The balance sheet strength is a priority that guides every strategic decision. It allows us to deliver stable growth, sustainable earnings and attractive dividend for our shareholders. Our strategy for delivering these objectives is to harvest free cash flow from Genco, to invest primarily in the utilities for the benefit of our customers, invest in long term contracted assets, which meet our return requirements and return capital to the shareholders. 
Consistent with this capital allocation policy, we're announcing today an evolution in our dividend policy. Our board has approved a policy to raise our dividend by 2.5% each year for the next 3 years beginning with the June 2016 dividend. The dividend increase shows our commitment to provide an attractive total return proposition for our shareholders and reflect the shift in focus towards our regulated utility and long-term contract businesses. 
Our balance sheet and our cash flow profile support the shift of the dividend policy and maintain a high credit quality and investment-grade rating remains a top priority. We continue to derisk the company by growing our regulated business. This allows us to generate earnings with a lower risk profile. We remain as focused as ever on careful discipline use of capital. 
Let's turn now to 2015 results in each of our businesses and our goals for 2016. Despite a difficult year in the markets, we've delivered earnings of $2.49 a share in 2015, demonstrating once again our ability to run business as well and manage through even the most challenging environments. 
And our utilities 2015 was a record year for us in many respects and growing regulated business continues to thrive. We achieved a major earnings milestone, our utilities earned over $1 billion in net income delivering the highest utility earnings on record. We invested nearly $3.7 billion and needed improvements for our customers across the utilities, including the AMI and the grid modernization investments, significant gas and electric infrastructure and an innovative technology and customer-oriented systems.  Our track record for reliability and customer service has allowed us to earn solid returns. 
Our utility earnings on aggregate across Exelon is at 9.5% in 2015. Our returns reflect the constructive regulatory relationship in our territories. PECO received the unanimous approval for both its $127 million rate case settlement and a $275 million long-term infrastructure improvement  plan. BGE received approval for recovery of more than $200 million of energy efficiency and gas infrastructure replacement investments and at ComEd, we achieved our fourth consecutive year of constructed outcomes in our formula rate file. 
This year, we filed a rate reduction at ComEd, showing ability to contain costs and limit the impact of capital investments on our customers build even during the current smarter investment cycles. 
The utilities continue to drive high operational performance and that performance is getting better each year. Of the 26 metrics we tracked, 21 of them were best or second best ever in 2015, including reliability and customer satisfaction. 
As for our goals in the utility business in 2016, our first primary goal is closing the PHI transaction. At which point, we'll begin the important job of integrating PHI of the Exelon family utilities. 
We'll bring our management models to PHI utilities in the quarter to improve the experience of the customers in the region. we'll work diligently to develop and implement an effective regulatory strategy for PHI. We'll invest approximately $4 billion in our existing utilities to refurbish and modernize the grid to improve service for our customers. That is part of the $18 billion we'll invest in our existing utilities over the next 5 years. 
We will work to maintain first quartile operational and customer satisfaction numbers, while continuing to focus on productivity and cost management. 
Finally, we expect the decision in our November 2015 BGE rate case in June and we'll file our annual formula rate update at ComEd in April. 
By executing on these goals, we'll deliver one of the most compelling utility earnings growth stories. 
Our Generation business had a solid year. Operationally in 2015, Constellation performed well even in the face of weak markets. Nuclear capacity factor was 93.7. Refueling outage performance was very strong. 
Average refueling outage duration was 22 days, that's the lowest average since 2002. 
Our gas and hydro plants outperformed the dispatched matched targets. Our solar and wind assets were the same for the energy capture funds. 
Our power business went 15 months without unemployed ocean recordable incident. It's the-based safety performance ever. 
At Constellation, our generation to load matching strategy contribute meaningfully to the earnings. Our load serving business experienced growth in both power and gas. 
In 2015, we served 195 terawatt hours of wholesale and retail load, materially growing that platform from 155 terawatt hours the prior year.  We continue to have high customer wind and renewable rates. 
We are now top 10 marketer of natural gas and it significantly increased our delivery to retail gas to 720 bcf last year. 
In 2016, Exelon Generation will continue to operate world-class fleet of assets, the highest level of performance, while continuing to execute our strategy of growing the contracted Generation business with 350 megawatts of wind projects in development. 
At Constellation, we will achieve our targets of serving 210 terawatt hours of load across all wholesale and retail base using our commercial platform as both a risk management vehicle and an earnings driver. 
Each of our business is well positioned to continue strong performance in 2016 operationally and financially. We have some important priorities we are targeting in 2016. We'll continue our broad efficacy efforts to ensure that our unique class of nuclear assets are properly valued for the clean, safe and reliable attributes. 
Developments in New York for a clean energy standard is constructing. The leadership of the governor in New York has been very positive but more work needs to be done, and we will engage with key stakeholders in the state. We continued with our specific efforts with legislators and stakeholders in Illinois on the low carbon portfolio standard. 
We provided ample time to reach the resolution on the nuclear assets, suffering significant losses in the process. If we don't see significant results, we will make the economically rational decision. We continue to engage with MISO on a constructive reform to address the issues in zone. We're working in the states in which we operate and develop compliance for the clean power pool. 
This has been a challenging period for our sector. We are tackling those challenges aggressively. We're reducing our cost by $350 million. We'll continue to shift our business mix to a more regulated exposure, both organically with our $18 billion capital into our existing utilities over the next 5 years and through our strategic acquisition of Pepco will which will raise that number of capital investments to $25 billion over the next 5 years. 
The company remains on a solid footing. Our balance sheet remains strong, and we continue to run the businesses with the highest operational levels. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Jack for the financial details.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chris, and good morning, everyone. As Chris stated, we had a strong year financially and operationally across the company. For the full year, we delivered earnings of $2.49 per share and $0.38 per share for the fourth quarter. If bonus have n
componenttext:
Thank you, Chris, and good morning, everyone. As Chris stated, we had a strong year financially and operationally across the company. 
For the full year, we delivered earnings of $2.49 per share and $0.38 per share for the fourth quarter. If bonus have not been extended, we would have delivered earnings of $2.58 per share, meaningful exceeding the midpoint of our guidance range.  The appendix contains details on our fourth quarter financial results by operating company on Slides 21 and 22. 
My remarks today will focus on 2016 earnings and O&M guidance, our credit profile, the cost management initiative and an update of our gross margin disclosures. 
Turning to Slide 6, we expect to deliver 2016 full year adjusted operating earnings of $2.40 to $2.70 and $0.60 to $0.70 per share for the first quarter. 
While we anticipate closing the Pepco Holdings deal in the first quarter, our guidance as a standalone figure that assumes the equity and debt issued for the PHI deal is unwound during the year. The impact of extension the of bonus depreciation is included in the guidance. 
Our growing utilities earnings primarily reflects increased capital investment in distribution and transmission to improve reliability and customer service at ComEd as well as increased rates for PECO's recent distribution rate case, partially offset by higher O&M at PECO and BGE related to storm and bad debt costs. 
Our strong operating performance at our utilities is fostering a positive regulatory environment in all our jurisdictions and is evident in the transformation and allowed an earned return that we've achieved at BGE since the Constellation merger. 
BGE has improved reliability and customer satisfaction in every year as compared to 2012, the year of the merger, which in turn, has led to improved regulatory outcomes and earned our lease over the same period. 
Last November, BGE filed an electric and gas distribution rate case to Maryland Public Service Commission, requesting revenue requirement increases of $121 million and $80 million to its electric and gas distribution rates, respectively. The requested rates of return on equity in the application are 10.6% for electric distribution and 10.5% for gas distribution. We expect the Maryland PSC to roll on the rate case in the June time frame with the new rates going into effect shortly afterward the final order. The revenue requirement increases reflect the continued investment, including Smart Grid, being made at BGE to improve reliability and customer service. 
Constellation had an record year in 2015 driven by higher realized margins that benefited from a lower cost-to-serve our load and strong performance in our portfolio management group. 
In 2016, we expect a more normalized cost-to-serve load and portfolio management performance, which we expect will have a negative impact on our earnings relative to an extraordinary 2015. 
Overall at Exelon Generation, the earnings impact from normalized margins and higher decommissioning trust, partially offset by fewer nuclear outages and cost management efforts, result in a forecast decrease in ExGen's earnings range versus last year. 
Our cost management initiative savings in 2016 should largely offset the impact of inflation at ExGen where labor and wage inflation are significant components of O&M. 
For reference, more detail on the year-over-year drivers by operating company can be found in the appendix on Slides 23 through 26. 
Moving to Slide 7. As we've said in the past, bonus depreciation has a negative impact on earnings with a positive impact on cash. 
In 2016, it creates a rounded $0.09 earnings drag at the consolidated level with $0.06 impact at Exelon Generation and a $0.03 impact at ComEd. 
On the cash, increases cash flow by $625 million in 2016. 
Despite the negative earnings impact of bonus depreciation in 2016 through '18, we are affirming the CAGR of 3% to 5% for the enterprise and 7% to 9% for the utilities through 2018 that we disclosed at the EEI. 
In addition, the extension of bonus depreciation will likely have a further effect on Exelon as a whole after the closing of the Pepco Holdings deal. Once the merger is completed, and we begin the integration of PHI's operating, planning and regulatory functions, we'll provide an update on PHI's forecast and the resulting increase in impact on Exelon's forecast. 
On Slide 8, our top financial priority remains maintaining our investment grade credit rating and ensuring the strength of our balance sheet. The 5-year extension of bonus depreciation improves the free cash flow positioned at ExGen, which has a positive impact on our metrics. ExGen free cash flow over the 2016 to 2018 period is now projected to be $5.35 billion or $3.2 billion after taking into account committed growth capital. 
Since our EEI disclosure, Exelon Generation has commenced developing a further 350 megawatts of long term contracted wind projects in Michigan and Oklahoma. 
As you'll note on the slide, given our strong cash flow outlook, ExGen has declining debt EBITDA ratio, starting at 3.2 in 2016 and decreasing to 2.3x debt-to-EBITDA by 2018. 
Bottom line, we're growing durable earnings and shrinking debt. 
Turning to Slide 9. I will provide an update on the cost management initiative that we announced towards the end of last year. We recently finalized the savings initiatives in January and have incorporated them in our current long-range plan. 
As we mentioned at the EEI, the total identified savings are in the $350 million range where savings are split equally between Exelon Generation in our corporate shared services organization. $100 million of the savings at the shared services organization will be achieved within our information technology function with the remainder coming from various corporate functions such as finance, legal, Human Resources and supply. The corporate savings will be allocated roughly equally between Exelon Generation and the utilities. 
Overall, this means that roughly 3/4 of the total cost-savings for the company will hit the bottom line in Exelon Generation, while the remaining quarter of the savings will be realized at utilities, mostly passed on to our customers. 
As a result, we expected run rate earnings benefit from our cost management initiative of $0.13 to $0.18 per share beginning in 2018 with approximately 35% of the run rate savings achieved by the end of this year. 
Our proven track record of cutting costs were running our business efficiently gives us confidence we'll be able to achieve or exceed these savings. 
Slide 10 shows our 2016 O&M forecast relative to 2015. We project O&M for 2016 to be flat to 2015, and we expect a slightly negative O&M CAGR across the enterprise over the 2015 t 2018 period and a negative 1% CAGR at Exelon Generation. 
ExGen's year-over-year decrease is driven by a combination of factors: Fewer planned nuclear outages compared to 2015; lower pension cost and the impacts of the cost management initiative. 
The year-over-year increase at PECO and BGE is due to inflation and budgeting for normal storm and bad debt costs, which results in an incremental year-over-year O&M growth. 
Slide 11 provides our fourth quarter gross margin update. This quarter's gross margin update now includes the impact of Kewaunee RSSA to 2016 and 2017 total gross margin. 
As we saw the forward prices and heat rates for 2017 increase by the end of the quarter, we reduced our deviation to ratable. 
For 2017, we ended the quarter with a power position of 5% to 8% behind ratable on a total portfolio basis when considering our crossed commodity hedges. We then further behind ratable in the Mid-West approximately 13% to 16% when considering cross commodity hedges. We continue to align our hedging strategy with our views of the market. 
In 2016, total gross margin is flat to our last disclosure. As you know, we're highly hedged in 2016, which combined with the inclusion of Kewaunee RSSA allowed us to offset the impact of lower prices in 2016. 
During the quarter, we also executed on $50 million on both tower new business and non-tower new business. 
Total gross margin increased by $50 million in both 2017 and 2018. The increase in 2017 is partially driven by the Kewaunee RSSA, which mitigates losses, while the increase in 2018 is driven by higher power prices across most of the regions most notably in NiHub with round-the-clock prices increasing by in $0.64 per for megawatt hour. 
During the quarter, we also executed on $15 million of nonpowered new business for both 2017 and 2018. 
As a reminder, the appendix includes several schedules that will help you in your modeling efforts. That concludes our prepared remarks, and we'll now open up the line for questions.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. Can you talk in a little bit more detail about what your plan is and what the milestones are for making a decision in Illinois on the economic units? And can you refresh our memory on where we stand on the -- in terms of profit and
componenttext: A couple of questions. Can you talk in a little bit more detail about what your plan is and what the milestones are for making a decision in Illinois on the economic units? And can you refresh our memory on where we stand on the -- in terms of profit and loss on the 3 units that you had initially 1.5 years or 2 years ago identified as impaired?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. As you know, we were successful and PJM was successful while the capacity market redesigns. They gave some upside to the fleet in NiHub greatly helped Byron and added health to Quad Cities. But since then, as you've seen the downturn and the forward
componenttext: Sure. As you know, we were successful and PJM was successful while the capacity market redesigns. They gave some upside to the fleet in NiHub greatly helped Byron and added health to Quad Cities. But since then, as you've seen the downturn and the forwards, Quad Cities continues to be challenged and more neutral on cash flows in earnings, while maintaining the risk of operation. We continue to work on Clinton. Clinton is negative. We have 2 initiatives underway. One working with MISO on Zone 4 reforms, and we like the design to be more like the new PJM capacity market design. But that in itself will not save Clinton. As you know, there's a lot of work going on in Springfield with the administration and the legislature, and we have had very strong support from the leadership and the legislature and administration coming to a resolution on the energy outlook for Illinois. It's not only that the clean energy standard, but there's an environmental jobs, green jobs build and there's the utility of the future build that have to be negotiated together. There's been progress made in that dialogue, but it is critical that we have -- that we're able to present to the legislature this spring a combined package that ensures the financial viability of our assets as they contribute highly reliability in environmental or we will have to make the rational economic decision. It's our job to get the stakeholders together. We're working hard on that and to bring the leadership to employees a consensus package that's good for all Illinois and its customers. So we're in this spring time in Illinois, and we're hopeful that we can have reasonable hedge prevail and negotiated balanced outcome. And as I said, present that to leadership so that they can provide continued support.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the second question is so you guys are going to be based on your cash flow slides on Page 37 that you're going to end the year with a pretty substantial cash balance. And if I look at the cash flow profile you project through 2018, that sho
componenttext: Okay. And then the second question is so you guys are going to be based on your cash flow slides on Page 37 that you're going to end the year with a pretty substantial cash balance. And if I look at the cash flow profile you project through 2018, that should continue to grow, all things equal. Your debt-to-EBITDA is going to be sub 3. By my measure, you're trading at under 4.5x EBIT, EBITDA in valuation of the nuclear business. That basically implies that nuclear is a wasting asset, right, with $8.5 billion of debt on the balance sheet that you should be amortizing debt because these plants are going away in 10 years. I mean, what can you do to convince investors that this low gas priced environment doesn't ultimate drive these assets out of business because if they're 20- or 30-year assets and not 10-year assets, the stock is undervalued?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. First of all, there's more than 10 years on these assets. we had renewal great goes on to the late 2040s. The money producing plants are the larger unit sites that will run into the 2040s, that's Byron, LaSalle, Limerick, Peach bottom and they're pos
componenttext: Yes. First of all, there's more than 10 years on these assets. we had renewal great goes on to the late 2040s. The money producing plants are the larger unit sites that will run into the 2040s, that's Byron, LaSalle, Limerick, Peach bottom and they're positioned well in the markets and Peach Bottom is the 30s, I think. But the other is in the 40s. So we've got the long run left in this profitable plans. If the smaller units of the single site units cannot be profitable, and we can't get a market design, they will be retired and there is an upside based of of the department on free cash flow and earnings. We'll remove the drag. As Jack described, we're very focused on the debt-to-EBITDA ratios at the Genco and over this period of time, we'll be reducing over $3 billion of debt at the Genco and continuing to manage that matching our assets with our debt. We feel very comfortable where we're at, but it is a misnomer that the result there, that these are 10-year assets with a large debt profile on them. Jack, do you want to?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think you covered, Chris. I mean the goal is to create that fortress balance sheet to do the right things around our assets and sustain the profitability of the long life plans.
componenttext: No, I think you covered, Chris. I mean the goal is to create that fortress balance sheet to do the right things around our assets and sustain the profitability of the long life plans.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: If we go look at the dividend increase and kind of the 2.5% a year for the next 3 years, can you maybe share how the board thought about using capital to raise the dividend considering you already have a pretty healthy yield? And then what was the thought
componenttext: If we go look at the dividend increase and kind of the 2.5% a year for the next 3 years, can you maybe share how the board thought about using capital to raise the dividend considering you already have a pretty healthy yield? And then what was the thought process behind your 2.5% a year for those 3 years?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. We had -- as we talked back 3 years ago now when we had to restructure the dividend, we had grown the dividend at Exelon based off of the earnings and cash flow on a very volatile business, the Genco. We had to make the shift and take the pain at th
componenttext: Sure. We had -- as we talked back 3 years ago now when we had to restructure the dividend, we had grown the dividend at Exelon based off of the earnings and cash flow on a very volatile business, the Genco. We had to make the shift and take the pain at the time to refocus the payout and where that reliable cash flow would come from. We set out at that time after the merge with Constellation improving the performance for the customers, the reliability of BGE and along with that, improving the profitability. ComEd has done a phenomenal job improving reliability, making prudent investments as our shareholders have seen as you have seen that the strategic plan we laid out the years ago is paying off, and it's -- can be seen, it's transparent that by 2018, theoretically, the utilities will be covering the dividend. In discussion with shareholders and feedback at the end of the year, the certainty that -- and our confidence in the business needed to be fully displayed in dialogue with the board. We thought that we can make these increases. We've talked about the free cash flow, we talked about the balance sheet, and we're committed to that through 2018. I think it's positive sign in the right direction that we feel confident in our strategy going forward.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: Okay, got it. And then on the Pepco deal, I guess, you've kind of done the one month of -- we're waiting for the Commission to make a decision. I guess, A, have you heard anything or is there anything indicative of for the commission could make a decision; and b, if the deal does not get approved, how do we think about the full return of the previous raised equity in the debt retirement?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the Commission did state that they would take this matter up before our March 4 date, and that's our only commitment is to try this until March 4, and we can't get it by March 4, then we have to fold up and then start to execute on the debt reduction a
componenttext: So the Commission did state that they would take this matter up before our March 4 date, and that's our only commitment is to try this until March 4, and we can't get it by March 4, then we have to fold up and then start to execute on the debt reduction and the buyback of the equity issued, and that would start immediately, the plans, the contingency plans were in place by Jack and Stacy and the team and that execution would then start at that point.

componenttext: And, Dan, just for modeling convention what we assumed it would take us roughly 5 months to buy back the equity, and that has a $0.06 drag associated with it during 2016 on a standalone plant, and we'd assume we retire the majority of the debt associated with Pepco in March, which has a $0.01 drag. So all in, on a standalone basis, there's about $0.07 of drag in our EPS associated with PHI closing that out if we end up on a standalone basis.

componenttext: Praful, we're retiring about $3.6 billion over the next 5 years at ExGen. And I think that reminds us rather than targeting a specific number, I think more importantly, it provides us with a considerable amount of flexibility and insulation and allows us to position from a point of strength our merchant fleets to compete on a long-term basis. It's clearly differentiated from the balance sheet of some of our competition, and we think that, that will be a competitive advantage as we proceed through the coming years.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So from a dividend standpoint, in effect, what we do is we set a minimum from a payout ratio at the utilities. But we've got a lot of flexibility in how we can fund that growth. So rather than targeting a specific payout ratio in aggregate, what we're rea
componenttext: So from a dividend standpoint, in effect, what we do is we set a minimum from a payout ratio at the utilities. But we've got a lot of flexibility in how we can fund that growth. So rather than targeting a specific payout ratio in aggregate, what we're really looking at is a minimum payout ratio of utilities of 65% to 70%, and then we look at where best to fund the dividend as well as fund the investment in the utilities to grow the regulated earnings stream of the company at 7% to 9%.

componenttext: That's a possibility. But if you look at -- go back to what Jack said, a payout ratio of 65% to 70% by 2018, theoretically, with our earnings profile, the utilities would cover that dividend, and that's a theoretical position we wanted to be in because we need to make decisions on further capital infusion for necessary projects to drive customer satisfaction and reliability.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Mishanta, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the Exelon Corporation Q4 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I'll now turn the conference over to Mr. Franci
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Mishanta, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the Exelon Corporation Q4 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I'll now turn the conference over to Mr. Francis Idehen. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mishanta. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our fourth quarter 2015 earnings conference call. Leading the call today are Chris Crane, Exelon's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Jack Thayer, Exelon's Chief Financial Of
componenttext:
Thank you, Mishanta. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our fourth quarter 2015 earnings conference call. 
Leading the call today are Chris Crane, Exelon's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Jack Thayer, Exelon's Chief Financial Officer. They're joined by other members of Exelon senior management team, who will be available to answer your questions following our prepared remarks. 
We issued our earnings release this morning, along with the presentation, each of which can be found in the Investor Relations section of Exelon's website. 
The earnings release and other matters, which we discuss during today's call contain forward-looking statements and estimates that are subject to various risks and uncertainties. Actual results could differ from our forward-looking statements based on factors and assumptions discussed in the earnings release, today's materials, comments made during this call and in the Risk Factors section of the 2014 10-K and the third quarter 10-Q. Please refer to today's 8-K and the 10-K and the 10-Q and Exelon's other filings for a discussion of the factors that may cause results to differ from management's projections, forecasts and expectations. 
Today's presentation also includes references to adjusted operating earnings and other non-GAAP measures. Please refer to the information contained in the appendix of our presentation and our earnings release for a reconciliation between the non-GAAP measures to the nearest equivalent GAAP measures. We've scheduled 45 minutes for today's call. 
I'll now turn the call over to Chris Crane, Exelon's CEO.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Francis, and good morning to everybody. Thank you for joining us on our fourth quarter call. Before I go into the results, I want to take a moment to thank our crews who worked hard to restore power for our customers in Baltimore and Philadelphi
componenttext:
Thanks, Francis, and good morning to everybody. Thank you for joining us on our fourth quarter call. 
Before I go into the results, I want to take a moment to thank our crews who worked hard to restore power for our customers in Baltimore and Philadelphia affected by the January storms. 
BGE and PECO were able to restore approximately 22,000 customers throughout the weather event, keeping the average restoration times to less than 3 hours, which is a remarkable accomplishment given the challenges associated with traveling and the working conditions that has the storm intensified. 
I'll start off by reiterating our strategy and our capital allocation philosophy. The balance sheet strength is a priority that guides every strategic decision. It allows us to deliver stable growth, sustainable earnings and an attractive dividend for our shareholders. Our strategy for delivering these objectives is to harvest free cash flow from the Genco, to invest primarily in the utilities for the benefit of our customers, invest in long term contracted assets which meet our return requirements, and return capital to the shareholders. 
Consistent with this capital allocation policy, we're announcing today an evolution in our dividend policy. Our board has approved a policy to raise our dividend by 2.5% each year for the next 3 years, beginning with the June 2016 dividend. The dividend increase shows our commitment to provide an attractive total return proposition for our shareholders and reflects the shift and focus towards our regulated utility and long-term contract businesses. 
Our balance sheet and our cash flow profile support the shift of the dividend policy and maintain a high credit quality and investment-grade rating remains a top priority. We continue to derisk the company by growing our regulated business. This has allowed us to generate earnings with a lower risk profile. We remained as focused as ever on careful discipline use of capital. 
Let's turn now to 2015 results in each of our businesses and our goals for 2016. Despite a difficult year in the markets, we've delivered earnings of $2.49 a share in 2015, demonstrating once again our ability to run businesses well and manage through even most challenging environments. 
At our utilities, 2015 was a record year for us in many respects and growing regulated business continues to thrive. We achieved a major earnings milestone. Our utilities earned over $1 billion in net income, delivering the highest utility earnings on record. We invested nearly $3.7 billion in needed improvements for our customers across the utilities, including the AMI and the grid modernization investments, significant gas and electric infrastructure and an innovative technology and customer-oriented systems.  Our track record for reliability and customer service has allowed us to earn solid returns. 
Our utility earnings on aggregate across Exelon is at 9.5% in 2015. Our returns reflect the constructive regulatory relationship in our territories. PECO received a unanimous approval for both its $127 million rate case settlement and a $275 million long-term infrastructure improvement  plan. BGE received approval for recovery of more than $200 million of energy efficiency and gas infrastructure replacement investments. And at ComEd, we achieved our fourth consecutive year of constructed outcomes in our formula rate file. 
This year, we filed a rate reduction at ComEd, showing our ability to contain cost and limit the impact of capital investments on our customers build even during the current Smart Grid investment cycles. 
The utilities continue to drive high operational performance, and that performance is getting better each year. Of the 26 metrics we tracked, 21 of them were best or second best ever in 2015, including reliability and customer satisfaction. 
As for our goals in the utility business in 2016, our first primary goal is closing the PHI transaction at which point, we'll begin the important job of integrating PHI, the Exelon family utilities. 
We'll bring our management model to PHI utilities in order to improve the experience of the customers in the region. We'll work diligently to develop and implement an effective regulatory strategy for PHI. We'll invest approximately $4 billion in our existing utilities to refurbish and modernize the grid to improve service for our customers. That is part of the $18 billion we'll invest in our existing utilities over the next 5 years. 
We will work to maintain first quartile operational and customer satisfaction numbers, while continuing to focus on productivity and cost management. 
Finally, we expect the decision in our November 2015 BGE rate case in June and we'll file our annual formula rate update at ComEd in April. 
By executing on these goals, we'll deliver one of the most compelling utility earnings growth stores. 
Our Generation business had a solid year. Operationally in 2015, the Constellations -- in Constellation performed well even in the face of weak markets. Nuclear capacity factor was 93.7%. Refueling outage performance was very strong. 
Average refueling outage duration was 22 days, that's the lowest average since 2002. 
Our gas and hydro plants outperformed the dispatched matched targets. Our solar and wind assets did the same for the energy capture funds. 
Our power business went 15 months without unemployed ocean recordable incident. It's the best safety performance ever. 
At Constellation, our generation to load matching strategy contribute meaningfully to the earnings. Our load serving business experienced growth in both power and gas. 
In 2015, we served 195 terawatt hours of wholesale and retail load, materially growing that platform from 155 terawatt hours the prior year.  We continue to have high customer wind and renewable rates. 
We are now top 10 marketer of natural gas and it significantly increased our delivery of retail gas to 720 bcf last year. 
In 2016, at Exelon Generation, will continue to operate world-class fleet of assets highest level of performance, while continuing to execute our strategy of growing the contracted Generation business with 350 megawatts of wind projects in development. 
At Constellation, we will achieve our targets of serving 210 terawatt hours of load across our wholesale and retail base using our commercial platform as both a risk management vehicle and an earnings driver. 
Each of our business is well positioned to continue strong performance in 2016 operationally and financially. We have some important priorities we are targeting in 2016. We'll continue our broad efficacy efforts to ensure that our unique class of nuclear assets are properly valued for the clean, safe and reliable attributes. 
Developments in New York for a clean energy standard are constructing. The leadership of the governor in New York has been very positive, but more work needs to be done. Then we will engage with key stakeholders in the state. We continue with our specific efforts with legislators and stakeholders in Illinois on the low carbon portfolio standard. 
We provided ample time to reach the resolution on the nuclear assets, suffering significant losses in the process. If we don't see significant results, we will make the economically rational decision. We continue to engage with MISO on a constructive reform to address the issues in Zone 4. We'll work in the states in which we operate to develop compliance plans for the clean power pool. 
This has been a challenging period for our sector. We are tackling those challenges aggressively. We're reducing our costs by $350 million. We'll continue to shift our business mix to more regulated exposure, both organically with our $18 billion capital into our existing utilities over the next 5 years and through our strategic acquisition of Pepco, which will raise that number of capital investment to $25 billion over the next 5 years. 
The company remains on a solid footing. Our balance sheet remains strong, and we continue to run the businesses with the highest operational levels. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Jack for the financial details.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chris, and good morning, everyone. As Chris stated, we had a strong year financially and operationally across the company. For the full year, we delivered earnings of $2.49 per share and $0.38 per share for the fourth quarter. If bonus had no
componenttext:
Thank you, Chris, and good morning, everyone. As Chris stated, we had a strong year financially and operationally across the company. 
For the full year, we delivered earnings of $2.49 per share and $0.38 per share for the fourth quarter. If bonus had not been extended, we would have delivered earnings of $2.58 per share, meaningfully exceeding the midpoint of our guidance range.  The appendix contains details on our fourth quarter financial results by operating company on Slides 21 and 22. 
My remarks today will focus on 2016 earnings and O&M guidance, our credit profile, the cost management initiative and an update of our gross margin disclosures. 
Turning to Slide 6, we expect to deliver 2016 full year adjusted operating earnings of $2.40 to $2.70 and $0.60 to $0.70 per share for the first quarter. 
While we anticipate closing the Pepco Holdings deal in the first quarter, our guidance is the standalone figure that assumes the equity and debt issued for the PHI deal is unwound during the year. The impact of the extension of bonus depreciation is included in the guidance. 
Our growing utilities earnings primarily reflects increased capital investment in distribution and transmission to improve reliability and customer service at ComEd, as well as increased rates for PECO's recent distribution rate case, partially offset by higher O&M at PECO and BGE related to storm and bad debt costs. 
Our strong operating performance at our utilities is fostering a positive regulatory environment in all our jurisdictions and is evident in the transformation it allowed and earned returns that we've achieved at BGE since the Constellation merger. 
BGE has improved reliability and customer satisfaction in every year as compared to 2012, the year of the merger, which in turn, has led to improved regulatory outcomes and earned ROEs over that same period. 
Last November, BGE filed an electric and gas distribution rate case with the Maryland Public Service Commission, requesting revenue requirement increases of $121 million and $80 million to its electric and gas distribution rates, respectively. The requested rates of return on equity in the application are 10.6% for electric distribution and 10.5% for gas distribution. We expect the Maryland PSC to rule on the rate case in the June time frame with the new rates going into effect shortly after the final order. The revenue requirement increases reflect the continued investment, including Smart Grid being made at BGE to improve reliability and customer service. 
Constellation had an record year in 2015, driven by higher realized margins that benefited from a lower cost-to-serve our load and strong performance in our portfolio management group. 
In 2016, we expect a more normalized cost-to-serve load and portfolio management performance, which we expect will have a negative impact on our earnings relative to an extraordinary 2015. 
Overall, at Exelon Generation, the earnings impact from normalized margins and higher decommissioning costs, partially offset by fewer nuclear outages and cost management efforts, result in a forecast decrease in ExGen's earnings range versus last year. 
Our cost management initiative savings in 2016 should largely offset the impact of inflation at ExGen where labor and wage inflation are significant components of O&M. 
For reference, more detail on the year-over-year drivers by operating company can be found in the appendix on Slides 23 through 26. 
Moving to Slide 7. As we've said in the past, bonus depreciation has a negative impact on earnings, but a positive impact on cash. 
In 2016, it creates a rounded $0.09 earnings drag at the consolidated level with the $0.06 impact at Exelon Generation and a $0.03 impact at ComEd. 
On the cash front, it increases cash flow by $625 million in 2016. 
Despite the negative earnings impact of bonus depreciation in 2016 through '18, we are affirming the CAGR of 3% to 5% for the enterprise and 7% to 9% for the utilities through 2018 that we disclosed at EEI. 
In addition, the extension of bonus depreciation will likely have a further effect on Exelon as a whole after the closing of the Pepco Holdings deal. Once the merger is completed, and we begin the integration of PHI's operating, planning and regulatory functions, we'll provide an update on PHI's forecast and the resulting increase in impact on Exelon's forecast. 
On Slide 8, our top financial priority remains maintaining our investment grade credit rating and ensuring the strength of our balance sheet. The 5-year extension of bonus depreciation improves the free cash flow positioned at ExGen, which has a positive impact on our FFO to debt metrics. ExGen free cash flow over the 2016 to 2018 period is now projected to be $5.35 billion or $3.2 billion after taking into account committed growth capital. 
Since our EEI disclosure, Exelon Generation has commenced developing a further 350 megawatts of long-term contracted wind projects in Michigan and Oklahoma. 
As you'll note on the slide, given our strong cash flow outlook, ExGen has declining debt-to-EBITDA ratio, starting at 3.2x in 2016 and decreasing to 2.3x debt-to-EBITDA by 2018. 
Bottom line, we're growing durable earnings and shrinking debt. 
Turning to Slide 9. I will provide an update on the cost management initiative that we announced towards the end of last year. We recently finalized the savings initiatives in January and have incorporated them into our -- in our current long-range plan. 
As we mentioned at EEI, the total identified savings are in the $350 million range with savings split equally between Exelon Generation and our corporate shared services organization. $100 million of the savings at the shared services organization will be achieved within our information technology function with the remainder coming from various corporate functions such as finance, legal, Human Resources and supply. The corporate savings will be allocated roughly equally between Exelon Generation and the utilities. 
Overall, this means that roughly 3/4 of the total cost savings for the company will hit the bottom line at Exelon Generation, while the remaining 1/4 of the savings will be realized at utilities, mostly passed on to our customers. 
As a result, we expected run rate earnings benefit from our cost management initiative of $0.13 to $0.18 per share beginning in 2018, with approximately 35% of the run rate savings achieved by the end of this year. 
Our proven track record of cutting costs and running our business efficiently gives us confidence we'll be able to achieve or exceed these savings. 
Slide 10 shows our 2016 O&M forecast relative to 2015. We project O&M for 2016 to be flat to 2015, and we expect a slightly negative O&M CAGR across the enterprise over the 2015 to 2018 period, and a negative 1% CAGR at Exelon Generation. 
ExGen's year-over-year decrease is driven by a combination of factors: Fewer planned nuclear outages compared to 2015; lower pension costs; and the impacts of the cost management initiative. 
The year-over-year increase at PECO and BGE is due to inflation and budgeting for normal storm and bad debt costs, which results in the incremental year-over-year O&M growth. 
Slide 11 provides our fourth quarter gross margin update. This quarter's gross margin update now includes the impact of the Ginna RSSA to 2016 and 2017 total gross margin. 
As we saw, the forward prices and heat rates for 2017 increase by the end of the quarter, we reduced our deviation to ratable. 
For 2017, we ended the quarter with a power position of 5% to 8% behind ratable on a total portfolio basis when considering our crossed commodity hedges. We're then further behind ratable in the Mid-West, approximately 13% to 16% when considering cross commodity hedges. We continue to align our hedging strategy with our views on the market. 
In 2016, total gross margin is flat to our last disclosure. As you know, we're highly hedged in 2016, which combined with the inclusion of the Ginna RSSA allowed us to offset the impacts of lower prices in 2016. 
During the quarter, we also executed on $50 million of both tower new business and non-tower new business. 
Total gross margin increased by $50 million in both 2017 and 2018. The increase in 2017 is partially driven by the Ginna RSSA, which mitigates losses, while the increase in 2018 is driven by higher power prices across most of the regions, most notably in NiHub with the round-the-clock prices increasing by in $0.64 per megawatt hour. 
During the quarter, we also executed on $15 million of non-power new business for both 2017 and 2018. 
As a reminder, the appendix includes several schedules that will help you in your modeling efforts. That concludes our prepared remarks, and we'll now open up the line for questions.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Greg Gordon with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Greg Gordon with Evercore ISI.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. Can you talk in a little bit more detail about what your plan is and what the milestones are for making a decision in Illinois on the -- on economic units? And can you refresh our memory on where we stand on the -- in terms of profi
componenttext: A couple of questions. Can you talk in a little bit more detail about what your plan is and what the milestones are for making a decision in Illinois on the -- on economic units? And can you refresh our memory on where we stand on the -- in terms of profit and loss on the 3 units that you had initially 1.5 years or 2 years ago identified as impaired?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. As you know, we were successful and PJM was successful while the capacity market redesigns. They gave some upside to the fleet in NiHub, greatly helped Byron and added health to Quad Cities. But since then, as you've seen the downturn and the forwar
componenttext: Sure. As you know, we were successful and PJM was successful while the capacity market redesigns. They gave some upside to the fleet in NiHub, greatly helped Byron and added health to Quad Cities. But since then, as you've seen the downturn and the forwards, Quad Cities continues to be challenged and more neutral on cash flows in earnings, while maintaining the risk of operation. We continue to work on Clinton. Clinton is negative. We have 2 initiatives underway. One working with MISO on Zone 4 reforms, and we like the design to be more like the new PJM capacity market design. But that in itself will not save Clinton. As you know, there's a lot of work going on in Springfield with the administration and the legislature, and we have had a very strong support from the leadership and the legislature and the administration by coming to a resolution on the energy outlook for Illinois. It's not only that the clean energy standard, but there's an environmental jobs, green jobs build and there's the utility of the future build that have to be negotiated together. There's been progress made in that dialogue, but it is critical that we have -- that we're able to present to the legislature this spring a combined package that ensures the financial viability of our assets as they contribute highly reliability in environmental or we will have to make the rational economic decision. It's our job to get the stakeholders together. We're working hard on that and to bring the leadership what was the consensus package that's good for all of Illinois and its customers. So we're in this spring time in Illinois, and we're hopeful that we can have reasonable hedge prevail and negotiate a balanced outcome. And as I said, present that to leadership so they can provide continued support.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So Quad, because of that further decline in gas prices and power prices since the CP result has gone back out of the money, so is that a fair summary?
componenttext: Okay. So Quad, because of that further decline in gas prices and power prices since the CP result has gone back out of the money, so is that a fair summary?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It is, it is. With these forwards, it is.
componenttext: It is, it is. With these forwards, it is.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And the second question is so you guys are going to -- based on your cash flow slide on Page 37, that you're going to end the year with a pretty substantial cash balance. And if I look at the cash flow profile you project through 2018, that should c
componenttext: Okay. And the second question is so you guys are going to -- based on your cash flow slide on Page 37, that you're going to end the year with a pretty substantial cash balance. And if I look at the cash flow profile you project through 2018, that should continue to grow, all things equal. Your debt-to-EBITDA is going to be sub 3. By my measure, you're trading at under 4.5x EBITDA on the -- implied valuation of the nuclear business. That basically implies that, that -- the nuclear is a wasting asset, right, with $8.5 billion of debt on the balance sheet that you should be amortizing debt because these plants are going away in 10 years. I mean, what can you do to convince investors that this low gas price environment doesn't ultimate drive these assets out of business, because if they're 20- or 30-year assets and not 10-year assets, the stock is undervalued?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. First of all, there's more than 10 years on these assets. We got license renewal of Braidwood, it great goes into the late 2040s. The money producing plants are the larger drill unit sites that will run into the 2040s, that's Byron, Braidwood, LaSall
componenttext: Yes. First of all, there's more than 10 years on these assets. We got license renewal of Braidwood, it great goes into the late 2040s. The money producing plants are the larger drill unit sites that will run into the 2040s, that's Byron, Braidwood, LaSalle, Limerick, Peach Bottom and they're positioned well in the markets and Peach Bottom is in the 30s, I think. But the others are in the 40s. So we've got a long run left on this profitable plants. If the smaller units or the single site units cannot be profitable, and we can't get a market design, they will be retired and there is an upside based off of that retirement on free cash flow and earnings. We will remove the drag. As Jack described, we're very focused on the debt-to-EBITDA ratios at the Genco. And over this period of time, we'll be reducing over $3 billion of debt at the Genco in continuing to manage that matching our assets with our debt. We feel very comfortable where we're at, but it is a misnomer that the result there that these are 10-year assets with a large debt profile on them. Jack, do you want to?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think you covered it Chris. I mean the goal is to create that workers balance sheet to do the right things around our assets and sustain the profitability of the long life plants.
componenttext: No, I think you covered it Chris. I mean the goal is to create that workers balance sheet to do the right things around our assets and sustain the profitability of the long life plants.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from Dan Eggers with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: If we go look at the dividend increase and kind of the 2.5% a year for the next 3 years. Can you maybe share how the board thought about using capital to raise the dividend considering you already have a pretty healthy yield? And then what was the thought
componenttext: If we go look at the dividend increase and kind of the 2.5% a year for the next 3 years. Can you maybe share how the board thought about using capital to raise the dividend considering you already have a pretty healthy yield? And then what was the thought process behind your 2.5% a year for those 3 years?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. We had -- as we talked back 3 years ago now when we had to restructure the dividend, we had grown the dividend at Exelon based off of the earnings and cash flow on a very volatile business, the Genco. We had to make the shift and take the pain at th
componenttext: Sure. We had -- as we talked back 3 years ago now when we had to restructure the dividend, we had grown the dividend at Exelon based off of the earnings and cash flow on a very volatile business, the Genco. We had to make the shift and take the pain at the time to refocus the payout in where that reliable cash flow would come from. We set out at that time after the merge with Constellation improving the performance for the customers, the reliability of BGE and along with that, improving the profitability. ComEd has done a phenomenal job improving reliability, making prudent investments and as our shareholders have seen as you have seen that the strategic plan we laid a few years ago is paying off, and it's -- can be seen, it's transparent that by 2018, theoretically, the utilities would be covering the dividend. In discussion with shareholders and feedback at the end of the year, the certainty that -- and our confidence in the business needed to be fully displayed in dialogue with the board. We thought that we can make these increases. We've talked about the free cash flow, we've talked about the balance sheet, and we're committed to that through 2018. I think it's a positive sign in the right direction that we feel confident in our strategy going forward.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. And then on the Pepco deal, I guess, you've ever kind of done the one month of room for the Commission to make a decision. I guess, A, have you heard anything or is there anything indicative of where the commission could make a decision? And
componenttext: Okay, got it. And then on the Pepco deal, I guess, you've ever kind of done the one month of room for the Commission to make a decision. I guess, A, have you heard anything or is there anything indicative of where the commission could make a decision? And b, if the deal does not get approved, how do we think about the full return of the previously raised equity in the debt retirement?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the Commission did state that they would take this matter up before our March 4 date, and that's our only commitment is to try this until March 4, and if we can't get it by March 4, then we have to fold up and then start to execute on the debt reductio
componenttext: So the Commission did state that they would take this matter up before our March 4 date, and that's our only commitment is to try this until March 4, and if we can't get it by March 4, then we have to fold up and then start to execute on the debt reduction and the buyback of the equity issued. And that would start immediately, the plans, the contingency plans were in place by Jack and Stacy and the team and that execution would then start at that point.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And, Dan, just for modeling convention what we've assumed is it takes us roughly 5 months to buy back the equity, and that has a $0.06 drag associated with it during 2016 on a standalone plan, and we'd assume we retire the majority of the debt associated
componenttext: And, Dan, just for modeling convention what we've assumed is it takes us roughly 5 months to buy back the equity, and that has a $0.06 drag associated with it during 2016 on a standalone plan, and we'd assume we retire the majority of the debt associated with Pepco in March, which has a $0.01 drag. So all in, on a standalone basis, there's about $0.07 of drag in our EPS associated with PHI closing that out if we end up on a standalone basis.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: And I think the disclosure in the back of the $1.6 billion or whatever buyback that you have in appendix, that's based on just buying back the same number of shares you originally issued, although the notional amount is obviously less than you raised. And is there a possibility you guys could buy back the amount you raised rather than the number of shares?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: To your point, what we've modeled is buying back the 57.5 million shares that we issued for the transaction. I think our balance sheet strength and where we see that orienting from a debt-to-EBITDA basis provides a lot of flexibility and we'll review what's the best means of creating value for shareholders.

componenttext: Actually going back to this debt question at ExGen. I just want to understand, given the goal is to harvest cash from ExGen as you pointed out and to reinvest that cash. componenttextpreview: Praful, we're retiring about $3.6 billion over the next 5 years at ExGen. And I think that reminds us rather than targeting a specific number, I think more importantly, it provides us with a considerable amount of flexibility and insulation and allows us
componenttext: Praful, we're retiring about $3.6 billion over the next 5 years at ExGen. And I think that reminds us rather than targeting a specific number, I think more importantly, it provides us with a considerable amount of flexibility and insulation and allows us to position from a point of strength our merchant fleets to compete on a long-term basis. It's clearly differentiated from the balance sheets of some of our competition, and we think that, that will be a competitive advantage as we proceed through the coming years.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. And then secondly, in terms of the dividend, if the Pepco transaction going to close, as you grow your dividend by the 2.5% as you've talked about, how are you looking at the payout ratio relative to just the utility earnings by 2018? And is ther
componenttext: Got you. And then secondly, in terms of the dividend, if the Pepco transaction going to close, as you grow your dividend by the 2.5% as you've talked about, how are you looking at the payout ratio relative to just the utility earnings by 2018? And is there a target level that you're comfortable with in terms of pay out relative to just utility earnings?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So from a dividend standpoint, in effect, what we do is we set a minimum from a payout ratio at the utilities. But we've got a lot of flexibility in how we can fund that growth. So rather than targeting a specific payout ratio in aggregate, what we're rea
componenttext: So from a dividend standpoint, in effect, what we do is we set a minimum from a payout ratio at the utilities. But we've got a lot of flexibility in how we can fund that growth. So rather than targeting a specific payout ratio in aggregate, what we're really looking at is a minimum payout ratio at utilities of 65% to 70%, and then we look at where best to fund the dividend as well as fund the investment in utilities to grow the regulated earnings stream of the company at 7% and 9%.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. So there is a scenario where the payout from just the utility business, or I guess, the total payout relative to the utility earnings could go higher than the 70% if in case the Pepco transaction doesn't close?
componenttext: Got you. So there is a scenario where the payout from just the utility business, or I guess, the total payout relative to the utility earnings could go higher than the 70% if in case the Pepco transaction doesn't close?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a possibility. But if you look at -- go back to what Jack said, a payout ratio of 65% to 70% by 2018, theoretically, with our earnings profile, the utilities would cover that dividend. And that's a theoretical position we wanted to be in, because w
componenttext: That's a possibility. But if you look at -- go back to what Jack said, a payout ratio of 65% to 70% by 2018, theoretically, with our earnings profile, the utilities would cover that dividend. And that's a theoretical position we wanted to be in, because we need to make decisions on further capital infusions for necessary projects to drive customer satisfaction and reliability.

componenttext: So Barbara, let me start with your second question first, this is on a standalone basis so you'll note under the debt retirements that we have a further $1.875 billion of retirements here. You'll recall we have a significant gas program there where we're hardening and replacing infrastructure within our gas utility as well as we have significant investments in reliability on the distribution and transmission side.

componenttext: Barbara, the Commission has historically called a special meeting, they do that on 48 hours notice, so they could do it at one of their scheduled meetings. I think they moved back their meeting in February because of a conflict with [indiscernible]. But we wouldn't be surprised at all if the decision whether to approve the merger is not heard at one of their scheduled meetings, but rather would be set on 48 hours notice at a special meeting.

componenttext: So we would analyze the best shareholder capital return policy. We'd be looking at other further investments that can be made, that create stronger and continuing growth in our investment in the regulated utilities, but it will be analyzed. And as I said, we theoretically hit a target of a payout in 2018. We'll take into consideration the best uses of capital allocation at that point, and we would anticipate some growth continuing after 2018. There's a lot of infrastructure and technology advancements that are coming along that will benefit the customers and benefit reliability and drive much more productivity within our workforce. So it's something that we'll look at, and we're heading in the right direction.

componenttext: Good morning. As Chris said at the top as well, it's not a clean energy fund, but it's the 0 emission credit program that benefits nuclear. As Chris said at the call, they're in constructive development for us in New York. We still have quite a ways to go. But as a threshold, political matter. Having the Governor of the prominence of, Governor Cuomo step forward and propose few, compensating it we're fairly to keep it in business is important. And if we get the details right, I would -- those are parts [indiscernible] is kind of [indiscernible] with the industry. But we don't have the compensation details sorted out yet. The RSSA at Clinton will expire in March of '17, so practically speaking, we need to see the details for the New York program this year. Once we see those details, obviously is to provide incremental revenue that would factor into the put if that put factor occurs. But we don't have important details right now and level of compensation or how the procurement mechanism works. So it's all speculative until we do the work over the next 3 or 4 months and nail this down.

And like Joe said, we got a very supportive administration that recognizes the clean benefits of nuclear, and that's really appreciated.
